CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: The decent hole mobilities of both copolymers can be attributed to high crystallinity of the copolymers due to the highly coplanar structure of anthracene and DPP. It is also understood that the 3-fold higher chargecarrier mobility of PTATDPP than that of PTAFDPP arises from its stronger π-π stacking with a shorter d 010 , as discussed above. When the photovoltaic properties of copolymers are measured using PC71BM as an electron acceptor , it is found that the optimum blend ratio of polymer : PC71BM is 1 : 2 to afford the best PCE of both copolymers with the conventional device architecture of ITO / PEDOT : PSS / polymer : PC71BM / Ca / Al ( Fig. S2 and Table S1 † ). The best PCE was also achieved when o-dichlorobenzene was used as a solvent and the optimum thickness for the active layer was ca. 90 nm. The current density - voltage ( J-V ) characteristics of the optimized solar cells are shown in Fig. 4 , and the relevant photovoltaic parameters of the devices are summarized in Tables 2 and S2. † PTATDPP showed a best PCE of 6.69% ( V OC = 0.80 V , J SC = 12.3 mA cm^-2 , FF = 0.68 ) , while PTAFDPP showed a best PCE of 5.02% ( V OC = 0.76 V , J SC = 11.2 mA cm^-2 , FF = 0.59 ). Both copolymers showed higher V OC s than other DPP - based copolymers due to their low - lying HOMO energy levels. Both copolymers also exhibited high J SC s and FFs , indicating their decent ability for charge generation and transport. Therefore , the TA unit is a promising electron - donating unit for low band - gap copolymers with a low - lying HOMO energy level. When the PSC devices were fabricated with an inverted architecture ( ITO / ZnO / polymer : PC71BM / MoO 3 / Ag ) in order to further improve the photovoltaic performance , the PCEs of PTATDPP and PTAFDPP - based devices were improved to 7.02% and 5.22% , respectively ( Fig. 4b , Tables 2 and S2 † ) , mainly due to enhanced J SC s ( V OC s and FFs were not changed significantly ). It is noteworthy here that the PCE of over 7% of PTATDPP is the highest efficiency of anthracene - based low band - gap conjugated copolymers. In spite of the same band - gap of the two copolymers , PTATDPP shows slightly higher J SC and FF than PTAFDPP ( Fig. S3 † ). This can be ascribed to the closely packed microstructures of PTATDPP and thereby its high charge - carrier mobility than PTAFDPP. When the crystal structures of blend films of the copolymers with PC71BM were examined by XRD , the PTATDPP / PC71BM blend had strong and intense ( 100 ) diffraction while the PTAFDPP / PC71BM blend showed weak and broad ( 100 ) diffraction ( Fig. 2b ).

Let's think step by step.

1. "the highly coplanar structure of anthracene and DPP" - Here, Anthracene and DPP are the material names.
2. "PC71BM" - This is a material name. It is used as an electron acceptor in the photovoltaic properties measurement of the copolymers.
3. "ITO / PEDOT : PSS / polymer : PC71BM / Ca / Al" - ITO, PEDOT, and Ca are material names. Polymer is a general term and not a specific material name.
4. "o-dichlorobenzene" - This is a material name. It is used as a solvent in the fabrication of the photovoltaic devices.
5. "PTATDPP" and "PTAFDPP" - These are material names. They are the copolymers being studied in this paragraph.
6. "ZnO" and "MoO3" - These are material names. They are used in the fabrication of the photovoltaic devices with an inverted architecture.
7. "PTATDPP / PC71BM blend" and "PTAFDPP / PC71BM blend" - These are material combinations. They refer to the blend films of the copolymers with PC71BM.

Therefore, the material names in the paragraph are Anthracene, DPP, PC71BM, ITO, PEDOT, Ca, o-dichlorobenzene, PTATDPP, PTAFDPP, ZnO, and MoO3.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Material Name.

1. Anthracene
2. DPP
3. PC71BM
4. ITO
5. PEDOT
6. Ca
7. o-dichlorobenzene
8. PTATDPP
9. PTAFDPP
10. ZnO
11. MoO3

These are the entities that clearly refer to Material Names in the paragraph.

Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

| Material Name |
| --- |
| Anthracene |
| DPP |
| PC71BM |
| ITO |
| PEDOT |
| Ca |
| o-dichlorobenzene |
| PTATDPP |
| PTAFDPP |
| ZnO |
| MoO3 |

Paragraph: The decent hole mobilities of both copolymers can be attributed to high crystallinity of the copolymers due to the highly coplanar structure of anthracene and DPP. It is also understood that the 3-fold higher chargecarrier mobility of PTATDPP than that of PTAFDPP arises from its stronger π-π stacking with a shorter d 010 , as discussed above. The best PCE was also achieved when o-dichlorobenzene was used as a solvent and the optimum thickness for the active layer was ca. 90 nm. The current density - voltage ( J-V ) characteristics of the optimized solar cells are shown in Fig. 4 , and the relevant photovoltaic parameters of the devices are summarized in Tables 2 and S2. † PTATDPP showed a best PCE of 6.69% ( V OC = 0.80 V , J SC = 12.3 mA cm^-2 , FF = 0.68 ) , while PTAFDPP showed a best PCE of 5.02% ( V OC = 0.76 V , J SC = 11.2 mA cm^-2 , FF = 0.59 ). Both copolymers showed higher V OC s than other DPP - based copolymers due to their low - lying HOMO energy levels. Both copolymers also exhibited high J SC s and FFs , indicating their decent ability for charge generation and transport. Therefore , the TA unit is a promising electron - donating unit for low band - gap copolymers with a low - lying HOMO energy level. When the PSC devices were fabricated with an inverted architecture ( ITO / ZnO / polymer : PC71BM / MoO 3 / Ag ) in order to further improve the photovoltaic performance , the PCEs of PTATDPP and PTAFDPP - based devices were improved to 7.02% and 5.22% , respectively ( Fig. 4b , Tables 2 and S2 † ) , mainly due to enhanced J SC s ( V OC s and FFs were not changed significantly ). It is noteworthy here that the PCE of over 7% of PTATDPP is the highest efficiency of anthracene - based low band - gap conjugated copolymers. In spite of the same band - gap of the two copolymers , PTATDPP shows slightly higher J SC and FF than PTAFDPP ( Fig. S3 † ). This can be ascribed to the closely packed microstructures of PTATDPP and thereby its high charge - carrier mobility than PTAFDPP. When the crystal structures of blend films of the copolymers with PC71BM were examined by XRD , the PTATDPP / PC71BM blend had strong and intense ( 100 ) diffraction while the PTAFDPP / PC71BM blend showed weak and broad ( 100 ) diffraction ( Fig. 2b ).

Let's think step by step.

1. Hole mobilities: decent hole mobilities of both copolymers
2. Crystallinity: high crystallinity of the copolymers
3. Coplanar structure: highly coplanar structure of anthracene and DPP
4. π-π stacking: stronger π-π stacking of PTATDPP
5. d 010: shorter d 010 of PTATDPP
6. Photovoltaic properties: photovoltaic properties of copolymers
7. Blend ratio: optimum blend ratio of polymer : PC71BM
8. Solvent: o-dichlorobenzene
9. Active layer thickness: optimum thickness for the active layer
10. Current density - voltage (J-V) characteristics: current density - voltage (J-V) characteristics
11. Photovoltaic parameters: relevant photovoltaic parameters
12. HOMO energy levels: low-lying HOMO energy levels
13. Charge generation: ability for charge generation
14. Charge transport: ability for charge transport
15. Architecture: conventional device architecture of ITO / PEDOT : PSS / polymer : PC71BM / Ca / Al
16. Electron acceptor: PC71BM
17. Polymer structure: TA unit, anthracene-based low band-gap conjugated copolymers
18. Microstructures: closely packed microstructures of PTATDPP
19. Charge-carrier mobility: high charge-carrier mobility of PTATDPP
20. XRD: X-ray diffraction (XRD)
21. Diffraction: (100) diffraction of PTATDPP/PC71BM blend.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Property Name of Material.

PV.content:
Please identify the Values (number + unit) of material properties in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: The decent hole mobilities of both copolymers can be attributed to high crystallinity of the copolymers due to the highly coplanar structure of anthracene and DPP. It is also understood that the 3-fold higher chargecarrier mobility of PTATDPP than that of PTAFDPP arises from its stronger π-π stacking with a shorter d 010 , as discussed above. When the photovoltaic properties of copolymers are measured using PC71BM as an electron acceptor , it is found that the optimum blend ratio of polymer : PC71BM is 1 : 2 to afford the best PCE of both copolymers with the conventional device architecture of ITO / PEDOT : PSS / polymer : PC71BM / Ca / Al ( Fig. S2 and Table S1 † ). The best PCE was also achieved when o-dichlorobenzene was used as a solvent and the optimum thickness for the active layer was ca. 90 nm. The current density - voltage ( J-V ) characteristics of the optimized solar cells are shown in Fig. 4 , and the relevant photovoltaic parameters of the devices are summarized in Tables 2 and S2. † PTATDPP showed a best PCE of 6.69% ( V OC = 0.80 V , J SC = 12.3 mA cm^-2 , FF = 0.68 ) , while PTAFDPP showed a best PCE of 5.02% ( V OC = 0.76 V , J SC = 11.2 mA cm^-2 , FF = 0.59 ). Both copolymers showed higher V OC s than other DPP - based copolymers due to their low - lying HOMO energy levels. Both copolymers also exhibited high J SC s and FFs , indicating their decent ability for charge generation and transport. Therefore , the TA unit is a promising electron - donating unit for low band - gap copolymers with a low - lying HOMO energy level. When the PSC devices were fabricated with an inverted architecture ( ITO / ZnO / polymer : PC71BM / MoO 3 / Ag ) in order to further improve the photovoltaic performance , the PCEs of PTATDPP and PTAFDPP - based devices were improved to 7.02% and 5.22% , respectively ( Fig. 4b , Tables 2 and S2 † ) , mainly due to enhanced J SC s ( V OC s and FFs were not changed significantly ). It is noteworthy here that the PCE of over 7% of PTATDPP is the highest efficiency of anthracene - based low band - gap conjugated copolymers. In spite of the same band - gap of the two copolymers , PTATDPP shows slightly higher J SC and FF than PTAFDPP ( Fig. S3 † ). This can be ascribed to the closely packed microstructures of PTATDPP and thereby its high charge - carrier mobility than PTAFDPP. When the crystal structures of blend films of the copolymers with PC71BM were examined by XRD , the PTATDPP / PC71BM blend had strong and intense ( 100 ) diffraction while the PTAFDPP / PC71BM blend showed weak and broad ( 100 ) diffraction ( Fig. 2b ).

Let's think step by step.

1. "high crystallinity" - This is a qualitative description and does not include a value and unit.
2. "3-fold higher chargecarrier mobility" - This is a comparative description and does not include specific values and units for the charge carrier mobility of PTATDPP and PTAFDPP.
3. "optimum blend ratio of polymer : PC71BM is 1 : 2" - The value is 1 : 2, and the unit is a ratio of mass or volume.
4. "best PCE of both copolymers...ca. 90 nm" - The best PCE values are 6.69% for PTATDPP and 5.02% for PTAFDPP. The unit for PCE is percentage. The optimum thickness for the active layer is ca. 90 nm, and the unit is length (nanometers).
5. "Voc = 0.80 V, Jsc = 12.3 mA cm-2, FF = 0.68" for PTATDPP - These are the photovoltaic parameters of the device. The unit for Voc is voltage, the unit for Jsc is current density, and the unit for FF is a ratio without units.
6. "Voc = 0.76 V, Jsc = 11.2 mA cm-2, FF = 0.59" for PTAFDPP - These are the photovoltaic parameters of the device. The unit for Voc is voltage, the unit for Jsc is current density, and the unit for FF is a ratio without units.
7. "enhanced Jsc (Voc s and FFs were not changed significantly)" - This is a comparative description and does not include specific values and units for Jsc, Voc, and FF.
8. "PCE of over 7% of PTATDPP" - The PCE value is over 7%, and the unit for PCE is percentage.
9. "ca. 90 nm" - The optimum thickness for the active layer is ca. 90 nm, and the unit is length (nanometers).
10. "strong and intense (100) diffraction" for PTATDPP / PC71BM blend and "weak and broad (100) diffraction" for PTAFDPP / PC71BM blend - These are qualitative descriptions of X-ray diffraction patterns and do not include specific values and units.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Value of Material Property.

1. "best PCE of both copolymers...ca. 90 nm" - The best PCE values are 6.69% for PTATDPP and 5.02% for PTAFDPP. The optimum thickness for the active layer is ca. 90 nm, and the unit is length (nanometers).
2. "Voc = 0.80 V, Jsc = 12.3 mA cm-2, FF = 0.68" for PTATDPP - These are the photovoltaic parameters of the device. The unit for Voc is voltage, the unit for Jsc is current density, and the unit for FF is a ratio without units.
3. "Voc = 0.76 V, Jsc = 11.2 mA cm-2, FF = 0.59" for PTAFDPP - These are the photovoltaic parameters of the device. The unit for Voc is voltage, the unit for Jsc is current density, and the unit for FF is a ratio without units.
4. "PCE of over 7% of PTATDPP" - The PCE value is over 7%, and the unit for PCE is percentage.
5. "ca. 90 nm" - The optimum thickness for the active layer is ca. 90 nm, and the unit is length (nanometers).

Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Property Value".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.
